column3: What is docker
column4: docker is a tool that is designed to help developers create and maintain their apps in an easy and organized way. The way that this program achieves it is by utilizing what are known as containers. The developer can simply add his app (and all of the other required data) into the container and transport it to its destination

column3: What are docker containers
column4: docker containers are the tools that docker uses to pack and ship developer’s apps to their target destination

column3: What are docker ‘images’
column4: images are used to create the container within docker. This is done by issuing the “run” command.

column3: Did docker come up with the ‘container’ technology
column4: Nope
column5: not at all. docker is actually a semi-new project – there are multiple other development tools that offer containers
column6: same as docker

column3: How is docker better than other tools that use containers
column4: then
column5: docker utilizes the cloud to run its container-relate operations – something that not many other development tools use. Using cloud
column6: docker becomes much more flexible and adaptable to various different scenarios that might come up during the development or shipment processes. This is the main feature for why it is being quite heavily regarded
column7: especially when compared to other container-based developer tools.

column3: What is a dockerfile
column4: A dockerfile is exactly such a set of instructions. Developers provided docker with such instructions so that the program could do the job correctly
column5: with those specific parameters in mind

column3: Is the ‘container technology’ reliable
column4: The biggest companies in the world (such as Google
column5: Amazon
column6: Intel and so on) use and trust the container technology – this should be the best answer for if containers are a reliable technology to use or not.

column3: What are the three main types of docker components
column4: The Client
column5: the Host and the Registry.

column3: Will you lose all of your work if you accidentally exit a container
column4: No
column5: you won’t lose any information
column6: data and other parameters if you accidentally exit the docker container. The only way to lose your progress would be to issue a specific command to delete the container

column3: Can you use any other files for composing instead of the default YAML
column4: Yes
column5: yes you can and there are no clashings or any other types of unwanted occurrences – you can use it without a problem.

column3: What are ‘NameSpaces’ use for
column4: Basically
column5: NameSpaces isolate the docker containers from other activities or tampering with them.

column3: What is the single most important requirement for building a docker container
column4: The most important requirement for building a container with docker is the default image. This default image may vary depending on the code that you’re using.

column3: How does docker manage ‘dockerized nodes’
column4: A dockerized node can be any machine that has docker installed and running. Now
column5: when it comes to management
column6: the answer is pretty simple – docker can manage both in-house and cloud-based nodes. So
column7: whether the node exists in the area of the main computer running docker or it’s present on the cloud – it does not matter. docker will manage it without a problem.

column3: What are the main factors that dictate the number of containers you can run
column4: There are basically two factors that might limit the number of containers that you can run – the size of your app and your CPU strength.

column3: How is docker different from Hypervisor
column4: Hypervisor requires you to have extensive hardware to function properly
column5: while docker runs on the actual operating system. This allows docker to be exceptionally fast and perform tasks in a fluid manner – something that Hypervisor tends to lack.

column3: Does docker run on Linux
column4: macOS
column5: and Windows
column6: You can run both Linux and Windows programs and excutables in docker containers

column3: How far do docker containers scale
column4: Some of the largest server farms in the world today are based on containers. Large web deployments like Google and Twitter
column5: and platform providers such as Heroku run on container technology
column6: at a scale of hundreds of thousands or even millions of containers.

column3: How do I connect docker containers
column4: Currently the recommended way to connect containers is via the docker network feature

column3: How do I run more than one process in a docker container
column4: This approach is discouraged for most use cases. For maximum efficiency and isolation
column5: each container should address one specific area of concern. However
column6: if you need to run multiple services within a single container

column3: What platforms does docker run on
column4: Linux
column5: Microsoft Windows
column6: Cloud

column3: How do I report a security issue with docker
column4: If you are a docker Enterprise customer
column5: please file a support case. Otherwise
column6: please file a support case using the Account Support Form. Please include as much information as possible including the repository
column8: and tag where you suspect a security issue
column9: your name and email so we can contact you
column10: and any other information you feel is relevant

column3: Is mongoDB offered as a hosted service
column4: Yes. mongoDB Atlas is a cloud-hosted database-as-a-service

column3: How does a collection differ from a table
column4: Instead of tables
column5: a mongoDB database stores its data in collections. A collection holds one or more BSON documents. Documents are analogous to records or rows in a relational database table. Each document has one or more fields
column6: fields are similar to the columns in a relational database table.

column3: How do I create a database and a collection
column4: If a database does not exist
column5: mongoDB creates the database when you first store data for that database.If a collection does not exist
column6: mongoDB creates the collection when you first store data for that collection.

column3: How do I define or alter the collection schema
column4: You do not need to specify a schema for a collection in mongoDB. Although it is common for the documents in a collection to have a largely homogeneous structure
column5: it is not a requirement and To change the structure of the documents in a collection
column6: update the documents to the new structure.

column3: Does mongoDB support sQL
column4: Not directly
column5: no. However
column6: mongoDB does support a rich queryAnswer language of its own

column3: Does mongoDB support transactions
column4: mongoDB’s atomic single-document operations already provide transaction semantics that meet the data integrity needs of the majority of applications.

column3: Does mongoDB handle caching
column4: Yes. mongoDB keeps most recently used data in RAM. If you have created indexes for your queries and your working data set fits in RAM
column5: mongoDB serves all queries from memory.

column3: What is the role of profiler in mongoDB
column4: mongoDB includes a database profiler which shows performance characteristics of each operation against the database. With this profiler you can find queries (and write operations) which are slower than they should be and use this information for determining when an index is needed

column3: How do you see the connections used by mongos
column4: The following command needs to be used: db._adminCommand(“connPoolStats”)

column3: Why are data files so large
column4: mongoDB does aggressive preallocation of reserved space to avoid file system fragmentation.

column3: what is maven
column4: maven is a project management tool. It provides the developer a complete build lifecycle framework. On executing maven commands
column5: it will look for POM file in maven
column6: it will run the command on the resources described in the POM.

column3: List out what are the aspects does maven Manages
column4: maven handles following activities of a developer • Build • Documentation • Reporting • Dependencies • SCMs • Releases • Distribution • Mailing list

column3: Mention the three build lifecycle of maven
column4: • Clean: Cleans up artifacts that are created by prior builds • Default (build): Used to create the application • Site: For the project generates site documentation

column3: Explain what is POM
column4: In maven
column5: POM (Project Object Model) is the fundamental unit of work. It is an XML file which holds the information about the project and configuration details used to build a project by maven.

column3: Explain what is maven artifact
column4: Usually an artifact is a JAR file which gets arrayed to a maven repository. One or more artifacts a maven build produces such as compiled JAR and a sources JAR.Each artifact includes a group ID
column5: an artifact ID and a version string.

column3: Explain what is maven Repository What are their types
column4: A maven repository is a location where all the project jars
column5: library jars
column6: plugins or any other particular project related artifacts are stored and can be easily used by maven.Their types are local

column3: Why maven Plugins are used
column4: maven plugins are used to • Create a jar file • Create war file • Compile code files • Unit testing of code • Documenting projects • Reporting

column3: List out the dependency scope in maven
column4: The various dependency scope used in maven are: • Compile: It is the default scope
column5: and it indicates what dependency is available in the classpath of the project • Provided: It indicates that the dependency is provided by JDK or web server or container at runtime • Runtime: This tells that the dependency is not needed for compilation but is required during execution • Test: It says dependency is available only for the test compilation and execution phases • System: It indicates you have to provide the system path • Import: This indicates that the identified or specified POM should be replaced with the dependencies in that POM’s section

column3: Mention how profiles are specified in maven
column4: Profiles are specified in maven by using a subset of the elements existing in the POM itself.

column3: Explain how you can exclude dependency
column4: By using the exclusion element
column5: dependency can be excluded

column3: What is the difference between DELETE and TRUNCATE statements
column4: Delete command is used to delete a row in a table wheras Truncate is used to delete all the rows from a table.

column3: What do you mean by table and field in sQL
column4: A table refers to a collection of data in an organised manner in form of rows and columns. A field refers to the number of columns in a table.

column3: What are joins in sQL
column4: A JOIN clause is used to combine rows from two or more tables
column5: based on a related column between them. It is used to merge two tables or retrieve data from there

column3: What is the difference between CHAR and VARCHAR2 datatype in sQL
column4: Both Char and Varchar2 are used for characters datatype but varchar2 is used for character strings of variable length whereas Char is used for strings of fixed length.

column3: What is a Primary key
column4: A Primary key is a column (or collection of columns) or a set of columns that uniquely identifies each row in the table

column3: What are Constraints
column4: Constraints are used to specify the limit on the data type of the table. It can be specified while creating or altering the table statement.

column3: What is the difference between sQL and MysQL
column4: sQL is a standard language which stands for Structured Query Language based on the English language whereas MysQL is a database management system

column3: What is a Unique key
column4: Uniquely identifies a single row in the table and Multiple values allowed per table and Null values allowed too

column3: . What is a Foreign key
column4: Foreign key maintains referential integrity by enforcing a link between the data in two tables.

column3: What do you mean by data integrity
column4: Data Integrity defines the accuracy as well as the consistency of the data stored in a database. It also defines integrity constraints to enforce business rules on the data when it is entered into an application or a database.

column3: List the different type of joins
column4: There are mainly 4 Types of Joins : 1. Inner Join 2. Left Join 3. Right Join 4. Full Outer Join

column3: What is the difference between DROP and TRUNCATE commands
column4: DROP command removes a table and it cannot be rolled back from the database whereas TRUNCATE command removes all the rows from the table.

column3: Why java is platform independent
column4: Platform independent practically means “write once run anywhere”. java is called so because of its byte codes which can run on any system irrespective of its underlying operating system.

column3: Why java is not 100% Object-oriented
column4: java is not 100% Object-oriented because it makes use of eight primitive datatypes such as boolean
column5: byte
column6: char

column3: What are wrapper classes
column4: Wrapper classes converts the java primitives into the reference types (objects).

column3: What are constructors in java
column4: constructor refers to a block of code which is used to initialize an object. It must have the same name as that of the class. Also
column5: it has no return type and it is automatically called when an object is created.

column3: what are the various Types of Constructors
column4: There are two types of constructors: 1.Default constructor 2. Parameterized constructor

column3: What is the difference between equals() and ==
column4: Equals() method is defined in Object class in java and used for checking equality of two objects defined by business logic wheras “==” or equality operator in java is a binary operator provided by java programming language and used to compare primitives and objects.

column3: What are the differences between Heap and Stack Memory
column4: Stack memory is used only by one thread of execution wheras Heap memory is used by all the parts of the application.

column3: What is Polymorphism
column4: Polymorphism is briefly described as “one interface
column5: many implementations”. Polymorphism is a characteristic of being able to assign a different meaning or usage to something in different contexts – specifically
column6: to allow an entity such as a variable
column8: or an object to have more than one form.

column3: What are the various types of Polymorphism
column4: There are two types of polymorphism: 1.Compile time polymorphism 2.Run time polymorphism Compile time polymorphism is method overloading whereas Runtime time polymorphism is done using inheritance and interface

column3: What is runtime polymorphism or dynamic method dispatch
column4: In java
column5: runtime polymorphism or dynamic method dispatch is a process in which a call to an overridden method is resolved at runtime rather than at compile-time.

column3: What is association
column4: Association is a relationship where all object have their own lifecycle and there is no owner.

column3: What do you mean by aggregation
column4: Aggregation is a specialized form of Association where all object have their own lifecycle but there is ownership and child object can not belongs to another parent object.

column3: What is composition in java
column4: Composition is again specialized form of Aggregation and we can call this as a “death” relationship. It is a strong type of Aggregation. Child object dose not have their lifecycle and if parent object deletes all child object will also be deleted

column3: . What is a servlet
column4: java Servlet is server side technologies to extend the capability of web servers by providing support for dynamic response and data persistence.

column3: What is Request Dispatcher
column4: RequestDispatcher interface is used to forward the request to another resource that can be HTML
column5: JSP or another servlet in same application.

column3: What is the role of JDBC DriverManager class
column4: The DriverManager class manages the registered drivers. It can be used to register and unregister drivers. It provides factory method that returns the instance of Connection.

column3: What is Node.js
column4: Node.js as “an open-source
column5: cross-platform runtime environment for developing server-side Web applications.”

column3: What is the relation of Node.js with javaScript
column4: Though Node.js is not a javaScript framework
column5: many of its modules are written in javaScript. It allows the developers to create new modules in javaScript. Node.js is a virtual machine that leverages javaScript as its scripting language to achieve high output.

column3: What is the fundamental difference between Node.js and Ajax
column4: While Ajax is a client-side technology
column5: Node.js is a server-side javaScript environment.

column3: Explain the term I/O in the context of Node.js
column4: I/O stands for input and output. It is used to access anything outside of the application. I/O gets loaded on to the machine memory in order to run programs after the application is fired up.

column3: State where Node.js can be used
column4: Web apps
column5: Network applications
column6: Distributed systems and General purpose applications

column3: Which are the two types of API functions in Node.js
column4: Asynchronous
column5: non-blocking functions and Synchronous
column6: blocking functions.

column3: Explain the role of the Callback function in Node.js
column4: In Node.js
column5: the Callback function is used to cater to multiple requests made to the server. If there is a large file that is expected to take the server a long time to process
column6: the Callback function can be invoked to ensure that other requests to the server are uninterrupted.

column3: What is an error-first callback
column4: Error-first callbacks are essentially used to pass errors and data. By default
column5: the first argument is always an error object
column6: where the user needs to check if something is wrong.

column3: Which is the framework that is most commonly used in Node.js
column4: The most commonly used Node.js framework is “Express”.

column3: Define “event-driven programming
column4: It is essentially a programming paradigm where the program flow is characterized by events such as messages from other programs.

column3: Explain data binding in angularJS
column4: “Data-binding in angular apps is the automatic synchronization of data between the model and view components.

column3: What are directives in angularJS
column4: directives are attributes that allow you to invent new HTML syntax
column5: specific to your application. They are essentially functions that execute when the angular compiler finds them in the DOM.

column3: What are Controllers in angularJS
column4: Controllers are javascript functions which provide data and logic to HTML UI. As the name suggests
column5: they control how data flows from the server to HTML UI.

column3: What is angular Expression
column4: angular expressions are code snippets that are usually placed in binding such as {{ expression }} similar to javaScript.

column3: What is the difference between link and compile in angular.js
column4: Compile function is used for template DOM Manipulation and to collect all the directives wheras Link function is used for registering DOM listeners as well as instance DOM manipulation and is executed once the template has been cloned

column3: What are the characteristics of ‘Scope’
column4: Scope is an object that refers to the application model. It is an execution context for expressions. Scopes are arranged in hierarchical structure which mimic the DOM structure of the application.

column3: Explain what is injector in angularJS
column4: An injector is a service locator
column5: used to retrieve object instance as defined by provider
column6: instantiate types

column3: What is factory method in angularJS
column4: Factory method is used for creating a directive.  It is invoked when the compiler matches the directive for the first time. We can invoke the factory method using $injector.invoke.

column3: Does angular use the jQuery library
column4: Yes
column5: angular can use jQuery if it’s present in the app when the application is being bootstrapped. If jQuery is not present in the script path
column6: angular falls back to its own implementation of the subset of jQuery that we call jQLite.

column3: Can angularJS have multiple ng-app directives in a single page
column4: No. Only one angularJS application can be auto-bootstrapped per HTML document

column3: What are Google chrome Extensions
column4: Google chrome Extensions are applications that run inside the chrome browser and provide additional functionality
column5: integration with third party websites or services
column6: and customized browsing experiences.

column3: How can I set up chrome for extension development
column4: Click the chrome menu icon   and select Extensions from the Tools menu. Ensure that the Developer mode checkbox in the top right-hand corner is checked. Now you can reload extensions

column3: What technologies are used to write extensions for chrome
column4: Extensions are written using the same standard web technologies that developers use to create websites. HTML is used as a content markup language
column5: CSS is used for styling
column6: and javaScript for scripting

column3: Are extensions fetched from the web every time the browser is loaded
column4: Extensions are downloaded by the chrome browser upon install
column5: and are subsequently run off of the local disk in order to speed up performance. However
column6: if a new version of the extension is pushed online
column7: it will be automatically downloaded in the background to any users who have the extension installed.

column3: Can extensions make cross-domain Ajax requests
column4: Yes. Extensions can make cross-domain requests.

column3: Can extensions use 3rd party web services
column4: Yes. Extensions are capable of making cross-domain Ajax requests
column5: so they can call remote APIs directly. APIs that provide data in JSON format are particularly easy to use.

column3: Can extensions encode/decode JSON data
column4: Yes
column5: because V8 (chrome's javaScript engine) supports JSON.stringify and JSON.parse natively
column6: you may use these functions in your extensions as described here without including any additional JSON libraries in your code.

column3: Can extensions store data locally
column4: Yes
column5: extensions can use localStorage to store string data permanently. Using chrome's built-in JSON functions
column6: you can store complex data structures in localStorage.

column3: Can extensions use Oauth
column4: Yes
column5: there are extensions that use OAuth to access remote data APIs. Most developers find it convenient to use a javaScript OAuth library in order to simplify the process of signing OAuth requests.100
column6: Can two extensions communicate with each other

column3: Intellij shortcut to convert code to upper or lower case
column4: Ctrl + Shift + U

column3: How to search in all the files of a project in IntelliJ Idea
column4: Ctrl + Shift + F.

column3: Renaming a project in IntelliJ IDEA
column4: You can change the project name
column5: which is the name that is shown in the recent projects list
column6: like so: Go to Project Structure (Ctrl+Alt+Shift+S) → Project Settings / Project → Project name:

column3: Correct way to add external jars (lib/*.jar) to an IntelliJ IDEA project
column4: Steps for adding external jars in IntelliJ IDEA: 1. Click File from the toolbar 2. Project Structure (CTRL + SHIFT + ALT + S on Windows/Linux
column6: on Mac OS X) 3. Select Modules at the left panel 4. Dependencies tab '5+' → JARs or directories

column3: How to force Intellij IDEA to reread all maven dependencies
column4: Press Ctrl+Shift+A to find actions
column5: and input reimport
column6: you will find the Reimport All maven Projects.

column3: How do I add maven project into intellij idea if pom.xml is not in the root level
column4: File -> New -> Project from Existing Sources -> select the pom -> set the root directory to project_dir

column3: IntelliJ can't recognize JavaFX 11 with OpenJDK 11
column4: The Starting Guide is the place to start with Java 11 and JavaFX 11.The key to work as you did before Java 11 is to understand that: JavaFX 11 is not part of the JDK anymore . You can get it in different flavors, either as an SDK or as regular dependencies (maven/gradle). You will need to include it to the module path of your project, even if your project is not modular.

column3: How to resolve in intellij “Cannot resolve symbol” but still compiles code
column4: First of all you should try File | Invalidate Caches and if it doesn't help, delete IDEA system directory. Then re-import the Maven project and see if it helps.In some weird cases compiled classes may report wrong info and confuse IDEA. Verify that the classes from this jar report correct names using javap.

column3: Getting “NoSuchMethodError: org.hamcrest.Matcher.describeMismatch” error when running test in IntelliJ 10.5
column4: Make sure the hamcrest jar is higher on the import order than your JUnit jar. JUnit comes with its own org.hamcrest.Matcher class that is probably being used instead.You can also download and use the junit-dep-4.10.jar instead which is JUnit without the hamcrest classes.mockito also has the hamcrest classes in it as well, so you may need to move\reorder it as well

column3: Can't compile project when I'm using Lombok under IntelliJ IDEA
column4: I have fixed it in IDEA 12 by setting check box Enable annotation processing in: Settings -> Compiler -> Annotation Processors For IDEA 2016.2: Preferences... > Build, Execution, Deployment > Compiler > Annotation Processors

column3: How to add directory to classpath in an application run profile in IntelliJ IDEA?
column4: In Intellij 13, it looks it's slightly different again. Here are the instructions for Intellij 13: click on the Project view or unhide it by clicking on the "1: Project" button on the left border of the window or by pressing Alt + 1.find your project or sub-module and click on it to highlight it, then press F4, or right click and choose "Open Module Settings" (on IntelliJ 14 it became F12) .click on the dependencies tab.Click the "+" button on the right and select "Jars or directories...".Find your path and click OK.In the dialog with "Choose Categories of Selected File", choose Classes (even if it's properties), press OK and OK again.You can now run your application and it will have the selected path in the class path

column3: How to clear gradle cache?
column4: Gradle cache locates at: On Windows: %USER_HOME%\.gradle/caches/. On Mac/Unix: $HOME/.gradle/caches/.You can browse to these directory and manually delete it or run. rm -rf $HOME/.gradle/caches/ on Unix system. Run this command will also force to download dependencies.

column3: IntelliJ inspection gives “Cannot resolve symbol” but still compiles code
column4: First of all you should try File | Invalidate Caches and if it doesn't help, delete IDEA system directory. Then re-import the Maven project and see if it helps.In some weird cases compiled classes may report wrong info and confuse IDEA. Verify that the classes from this jar report correct names using javap.

column3: How do I turn off the unlimited whitespace in IntelliJ editor?
column4: File menu -> Settings -> Editor -> General -> Virtual Space and uncheck 'Allow placement of caret after end of line' . You may also uncheck the other options in the Virtual Space panel.

column3: Intellij - Unable to use newer Java 8 classes - Error : “Usage of API documented as @since 1.6+..”
column4: To get rid of this, you need to open up : File -> Project Structure -> Project Settings -> Modules -> "Your Module Name" -> Sources -> Language Level and change that to the desired level i.e 1.8 or the Project Default language level

column3: Error:java: invalid source release: 8 in Intellij. What does it mean?
column4: In IntelliJ 13.1.4 I had to change Java and SDK version on the following places not to get this error: File -> Project Structure -> Project Settings .File -> Project Structure -> Module Settings -> Tab: Sources: Language Level.File -> Project Structure ->Module Settings -> Tab: Dependencies: Module SDK. File -> Settings -> Compiler -> Java Compiler -> Target bytecode version

column3: IntelliJ Build Error Context Mismatch
column4: The cause turned out to be that I had defined a new configuration in the "Run/Debug Configurations" dialog and put the full path to the build.gradle file in the Gradle project: field, as follows. (I did this by clicking the ellipsis (...) button to the right of the field, but I could also have entered it directly.)

column3: IntelliJ says 'cannot run program '/path/to/tomcat/bin/catalina.sh' error=13 permission denied
column4: In short, from a console: chmod a+x /path/to/tomcat/bin/catalina.sh.This assumes that you 've elided the Tomcat path in your post, and checked that it really does exist on your system before posting here. Depending on the existing permissions of the file,you may need to issue the above command as a user with sufficiently elevated privileges.

column3: IntelliJ gives Fatal Error: Unable to find package java.lang in classpath or bootclasspath
column4: Somehow the JDK language jars were removed from the classpath. All I had to do was reapply the JSDK home path.Goto: File -> Project Structure -> Platform Settings -> SDKs Re-apply the JSDK home path.Doing this added about 15 jars to the classpath. Apparently these are important for compiling.
